Metal alloy catalysts have been known to enhance many essential reactions. Surface-adsorbate interaction of an alloy catalyst depends on the composition and nanostructure of the surface, which can be changed by a phenomenon called surface segregation. Thus, thermodynamic information on the surface segregation is critical to tune the surface-adsorbate interaction, and thus the reactivity of alloy catalysts. Collected 1,366 density functional theory-calculated segregation energies (E segr) from literature were featurized by 19-dimensional inexpensive numerical fingerprint, which represents facet-, site-, and elemental-dependencies. Deep neural network (DNN) model was constructed based on the data. Reasonable interpolative and extrapolative prediction by the DNN was clearly demonstrated using principal component (PC) analysis. On top of that, impact of each feature on the E segr was analyzed by an explainable artificial intelligence approach, giving useful insights for alloy catalyst design based on surface segregation. As an example of the applications, the DNN model was used to explain the formation thermodynamics of site-selective nanosegregated Pt alloy catalyst, and was also used to perform elemental screening to find impurity-host metal combinations feasible to form the nanosegregated alloy catalyst. In addition, the guidance for data collection to improve the DNN model was given by analyzing PC space and performing the weight analysis of PCs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Machine learning Metal alloy Surface segregation Density functional theory Explainable artificial intelligence Data availability The E segr data that were collected from literature and used for training ML models are provided as spreadsheets in Supplementary material. Other data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Metal alloy has been widely studied due to its wide range of applications in various fields, such as heterogeneous catalysis [1], medical devices [2], energy storage [3], and robotics [4]. The metal alloys can exhibit improved essential properties and/or can be more economically efficient compared with pure metals by selecting proper metal combination. For instance, metal alloy catalyst, compared with pure metal catalyst, may have different reactivity because alloy surface composed of several elements differently interacts with reactants or intermediates, leading to the change of catalytic activity [1]. Thermal energy and/or the adsorbate molecule on the metal alloy surface can induce the impurity metals in the bulk region of the alloy to segregate toward the surface [5], enriching the surface region; it is called surface segregation. The surface segregation leads to the change of alloy surface's composition, surface-reactant interaction, and thus the change of reactivity. On top of that, selective removal of specific element after the spatially heterogeneous surface segregation can lead to highly active hollow nanostructured catalysts [6]. Thus, the surface segregation is an important phenomenon because it is related with the reactivity change during chemical reaction or annealing process, and may be used to tune surface reactivity of alloy catalysts. Segregation energy (E segr), the energetic change upon the surface segregation, represents the thermodynamic favorability of the segregation (Fig. 1 a). Previous studies calculated the E segr for various surface environment, e.g., facet and coordination number (CN), and elemental combinations using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Ruban et al. calculated E segr for the 24 × 24 elemental combinations of single transition metal impurities and transition metal hosts with closed-packed surface using Green's function linear-muffin-tin-orbitals method [7]. Nilekar et al. also calculated E segr for the same 24 × 24 bimetallic elemental combinations but for open low-index surfaces [8]. Han et al. calculated 302 E segr for several transition metal impurity and host metals to identify thermodynamically feasible stepped metal surfaces decorated with impurity metal [9]. However, these works show that an extension of E segr’s elemental trend to other facet or CN requires additional 552 (=24 × 24 - 24) E segr calculations. Namely, calculating E segr for all the possible combinations of facet, CN, and element is computationally demanding. Using machine learning (ML) approach, complex relationship between surface-related variables and the E segr can be learned using E segr data previously calculated by other researchers, and the E segr behavior of unseen alloy surface can be predicted rapidly without costly DFT calculations. In this contribution, 1366 E segr data were collected from the above three previous papers and featurized with inexpensive fingerprint that is easily accessible in literature to make a ML model of E segr. Interpolative and extrapolative predicting abilities of the model were evaluated using experimental E segr data obtained by surface core-level shifts (SCLS) method and test data distributed outside the training/validation data region. Influential features to the E segr were identified by SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) value analysis within explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) approach. The trained E segr model was found to explain the formation thermodynamics of site-selective nanosegregated Pt–Ni alloy catalyst, and then was used to screen 552 impurity/host metal combinations to find other thermodynamically feasible combinations to form the nanosegregated alloy. In addition, data distribution was further analyzed using principal component analysis (PCA) and sparse PCA to present guidance for further data collection. This work is believed to show how to make a ML model learn published data to provide useful design knowledge and to discover feasible elements for metal alloy catalysts, being combined with data science techniques. 2 Methods 2.1 Data collection 1429 DFT-calculated E segr data were collected from three previous works by Ruban et al., Nilekar et al., and Han et al., respectively [7–9]. However, 126 data overlapped between those works; 40, 40, and 46 data overlapped between Han et al. and Ruban et al., Han et al. and Nilekar et al., and Ruban et al. and Nilekar et al., respectively (See the spreadsheets in the Supplementary material). These three works calculated E segr using DFT calculations with different approximations; In the previous work by Ruban et al., the DFT in local density approximation (LDA) was used with coherent potential approximation (CPA) and Green's function technique for semi-infinite surfaces within tight-binding representation of the linear-muffin-tin-orbitals (LMTO) method, where spd basis set was used [7]. In the work by Nilekar et al., the DFT in LDA with Perdew-Wang flavor was used with locally self-consistent Green's function (LSGF) technique and Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker-atomic sphere approximation (KKR-ASA) method, where spdf basis set was used [8]. In the work by Han et al., on the other hand, the plane-wave DFT in generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Wang 91 parameterization was used with plane-wave expansion cutoff of 241.6 eV [9]. Thus, each overlapped E segr value was different despite the same feature vector. This overlapping would necessarily increase the MAE values of the ML model to be trained, and thus wrong weight parameters will be captured during the training. Thus, the different E segr values for the same feature were averaged. In the end, only 63 unique E segr data were left in the database, leading to the 1366 E segr data to be used to train E segr model. The difference of E segr values between the papers may also be attributed to the difference in the impurity concentrations in the host metal slab models in DFT calculations. The E segr were calculated within single impurity limit in the works of Ruban et al. and Han et al. The E segr by Nilekar et al. were calculated based on single transition metal impurity; they used (3 × 3) surface unit cell for fcc(100) slab models, the size of which is the same with that of Han et al. Therefore, all the E segr by three papers were calculated in the single impurity limit, indicating that there is negligible difference of E segr due to the concentration difference. Hexagonal lattice systems, e.g., hexagonal close packed (HCP), usually use four indices (hkil), called Bravais-Miller index, using redundant index i, which obeys the constraint h + k + i = 0. The four-index notation is normally used for clarity, but the lattice plane of a lattice system basically can be denoted by Miller index (hkl), which is three-index scheme. Thus, all the collected E segr data of HCP host metal were featurized based on the Miller index for consistency of featurization, e.g., HCP(0001) → HCP(001), HCP(10 1 ¯ 0) → HCP(100). 2.2 Hyperparameter tuning of ML models and deep learning model Deep neural network (DNN) and conventional ML models, such as least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO) [10], random forest (RF) [11], extreme gradient boost (XGB) [12], were considered as models to learn the relationship between the E segr and the 19-dimensional numerical fingerprint. The LASSO is a linear model using weight decay method which suppresses overfitting, and was used as a base model to examine if the fingerprint and the E segr have a linear relationship. The RF and XGB are ML models based on bagging and boosting, respectively. Ensemble method, which includes the bagging and boosting, can increase the accuracy and generalizability of a single ML model by combining several models; thus, the RF and XGB were considered in this work. The hyperparameters of each model were optimized by Bayesian optimization scheme, implemented in KerasTuner [13], combined with 10-fold cross validation (CV). First, each feature was scaled by Min-max normalization. Initial (3 × number of hyperparameters) samples were used to construct Gaussian process regression (GPR) model. A N h-dimensional hyperparameter set was suggested by maximizing acquisition function (Tables S1-S4). Upper confidence bound (UCB) was used as the acquisition function: α UCB ( x ; β ) = μ ( x ) − β σ ( x ) , where the x is the N h-dimensional hyperparameter vector, the μ(x) is the mean value of the CV score at x estimated by the GPR, the σ is the standard deviation (uncertainty) of the estimated CV score, and the β is the weight to determine the portion of exploitation (μ(x)) and exploration (σ(x)). For the suggested hyperparameter set, 10-fold CV was performed; the accuracy of the model was evaluated using the mean of all the 10 folds’ mean absolute errors (MAEs) for validation set, which is called CV score. During each fold's training, Mean squared error (MSE) was used as the loss function, which will be minimized by the optimizer, but the MAE was used as the metric in early stopping and 10-fold CV to judge the performance of each trained model because the MAE shows the error values in physically intuitive scale of eV. The suggestion of feasible hyperparameter was repeated until the total 100 trials were exhausted, resulting in the optimized hyperparameter set to give the best model accuracy (Tables S1-S4). Particularly for the DNN, batch normalization re-centers and re-scales the input feature distribution at each hidden layer [14]. It has been known to alleviate vanishing or exploding gradient problem and to regularize the model, leading to less overfitting and better generalization, i.e., batch normalization stabilizes the training process; the stabilization also allows for the use of larger learning rate, speeding up the training process. Thus, the bath normalization was used for training each model in the 10-fold CV. Maximum epochs of back-propagation was set as 10,000, and early-stopping was used with patience = 1000 to mitigate overfitting during the training of each fold. 2.3 Calculation of SHAP values The calculation of SHAP (Shapley Additive exPlanations) values is based upon the additive feature attribution method, such that, f ( x ) = g ( x ′ ) = ϕ 0 + ∑ i = 1 M ϕ i x ′ i , where g ( x ′ ) is explanation model for a trained predictive model f ( x ) at a sample vector x with mapping of x = h x ( x ′ ) , x ′ is simplified input feature vector ( x ′ ∈ { 0 , 1 } M ; M: the number of simplified features), ϕ 0 = f ( h x ( 0 ) ) indicates that the output value without any feature. The SHAP value of feature i of the predictive model f for a single sample vector x can then be locally calculated as the average of marginal contribution of the feature i as follows: ϕ i ( f , x ) = ∑ z ′ ⊆ x ′ | z ′ | ! ( M − | z ′ | − 1 ) ! M ! [ f x ( z ′ ) − f x ( z ′ / i ) ] , where | · | is cardinality of a set, z ′ ⊆ x ′ indicates all the z ′ vectors (or subsets) where its non-zero entries are a subset of the entries in the simplified input vector x ′ , [ f x ( z ′ ) − f x ( z ′ / i ) ] indicates marginal contribution of the feature i to the output value; f x ( z ′ ) = f ( h x ( z ′ ) ) ; z ′ / i denotes z ′ i = 0 . The calculations of the SHAP value was implemented in SHAP python module [15]. Here, the f corresponds to the DNN model of E segr. 2.4 Principal component analysis (PCA) Visualization of high-dimensional data requires the reduction of dimension to lower dimension. The dimensional reduction can be performed by principal component analysis (PCA); PCA can project a multivariate dataset onto a set of successive orthogonal components that explain a maximum amount of the variance or information. The PCA finds new orthonormal axes v i ∈ R d × 1 that maximize the projected data's variance (or information). Data matrix D ∈ R n × d , where n is the number of samples and d is the number of features, is first centralized to make X ∈ R n × d by subtracting the elements of each column with the mean value of the column. The maximization of the variance of the X projected along the v i ( v i T Σ v i ; Σ = 1 n − 1 X T X ) turns out to be equivalent to choosing ith eigenvector of the covariance matrix Σ , indicating that the eigenvectors { v i } are the new orthonormal axes {PCi} or the principal components (PCs). The eigenvectors can be obtained by the eigenvalue decomposition (EVD) of Σ or the singular value decomposition (SVD) of the X . Because the SVD is usually known to be numerically more stable than EVD, the SVD was performed here using radomized method by Halko et al. [16], which is implemented in scikit-learn [17]. Herein, the PCA was performed to visulize the distribution of Min-max normalized 1366 19-dimensional data, used to train the machine learning models, in two-dimensional PC1-PC2 space. 2.5 Sparse PCA A PC can be represented as a linear combination of unit vectors in original feature space. During the maximization process of the PCA, the weights are determined, which are actually the components of a PC vector. The weight of each feature indicates how much the feature changes along with the PC. By analyzing the weight values, we can roughly see the distribution of each feature, categorize features into PCs, or obtain guidance for the data collection to improve the accuracy of the trained model [18]. However, regular PCA usually has disadvantage that PCs have non-zero weights for all the variables (features), making it difficult to interpret the PCA result. Sparse PCA can alleviate this disadvantage of the regular PCA by restricting the number of non-zero weights of the PCs. Thus, the maximization problem changes into, a r g max v i T Σ v i v i subject to | v i | = 1 , | v i | 0 ≤ k , where the | · | 0 indicates the L0 norm and the k the maximum number of non-zero weights. However, L1 norm is usually used instead of the L0 norm because the L0 norm constraint is generally NP-hard. Thus, out of various formulations of the sparse PCA, the L1 norm was applied here according to Mairal et al. [19], as implemented in the scikit-learn. By limiting the number of features with non-zero weight, interpretation of the PCA result can be clearer than the regular PCA. 2.6 Mapping DNN-predicted E segr onto NP structure to explain the formation of nanosegregated alloy catalysts To visualize the site-selectivity of surface segregation depending on the exposed site's CN, the corresponding E segr values were mapped onto each atomic site. (Fig. S1) First, nanoparticle (NP) structure of host metal was made following the Wulff construction or experimental characterization result. The CN of every site in the structure was calculated using atomic simulation environment (ASE) python module [20]. The obtained CNs were then used to get the ΔCN (=12-CN) feature to predict E segr using the trained DNN model. Each site was colored with the corresponding E segr value. Although facet cannot easily be defined for small NP structures, Miller indices features were set as h = 6, k = 4, l = 3 because the (643) is a facet that covers broad range of CNs from 6 to 12. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Featurization of surface segregation thermodynamics by inexpensive numerical fingerprint A property of interest can be characterized by several variables, called features, related with the property. Although the property and the features have complex nonlinear relationship, the relationship can be recognized by many advanced computational techniques. Recently, ML approaches have been widely employed to learn or parameterize complex relationships between target value and its effective features in many research fields [21–24]. Once the ML model is successfully trained on data, the target property is predicted only by the set of features, numerical fingerprint. Moreover, if all the features are easily obtainable without costly experimental measurements or theoretical calculations, the target value can be predicted rapidly even for unseen numerical fingerprints. The E segr was featurized by 19 features to make a ML model that can predict the E segr for various surface environments and elemental combinations (Fig. 1b). The 19-dimensional feature vector, used as the numerical fingerprint for the E segr, was composed of four structural features and 15 elemental features. The structural features comprise three Miller indices (h, k, l) and the loss of CN (ΔCN=12-CN), which is the CN difference between the segregation site at the surface and the bulk position (CN=12). According to previous studies [9,25–27], the CN was considered to be critical to the E segr, and the Miller indices obviously are closely related with the CN at a surface-segregation site because the indices represent the exposed facets, or nanostructure, of an alloy catalyst. Nilekar et al. also observed that negative (positive) E segr values of close-packed surfaces, such as fcc(111) and bcc(110), become more negative (positive) for open surfaces, such as fcc(100) and bcc(100), with the respective impurity/host combinations. The sign of E segr values were even reversed by the change of exposed facet for some combinations [8]. The elemental features comprise liquid surface tension (ε), Wigner-Seitz radius (r), Pauling electronegativity (PEN), ionization energy (IE), and electron affinity (EA) of impurity metal (F im) and host metal (F h), and their difference (ΔF) (5 × 3 = 15 features); ΔF = F im - F h. These elemental features represent the unique characteristics of a metal element, and have been used as ML models’ features to predict catalytic properties such as adsorption energy of reaction intermediate molecules [9,21,28]. Particularly, the ε is equivalent to the surface free energy of a solid metal, and can be used to characterize the bond strength of solid metal atoms; The bond strength difference between host and impurity metals has been known to be critical to explain the E segr [27,29]. As the size mismatch of the impurity and host can lead to strain [30,31], and thus the surface segregation, r of a metal was also considered as a feature. All the 19 features used for the numerical fingerprint can be chosen by user (structural features) or can be accessible from literature (elemental features) [32–37], so the ML model that will be trained using this inexpensive fingerprint will be able to promptly predict E segr for various combinations of structural and elemental features, even for the unseen data. 3.2 Construction of ML models and their prediction abilities Least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO), random forest (RF), extreme gradient boost (XGB), and deep neural network (DNN) were considered as ML models to learn the relationship between the E segr and the 19-dimensional numerical fingerprint. The hyperparameters of each model were optimized by Bayesian optimization scheme combined with 10-fold cross validation (CV) (Fig. 2 a). First, each feature was scaled by Min-max normalization. Initial hyperparameter samples were used to construct Gaussian process regression (GPR) model. A N h-dimensional hyperparameter set was suggested by maximizing acquisition function. For the suggested hyperparameter set, 10-fold CV was performed; the accuracy of the model was evaluated using the mean of all the 10 folds’ mean absolute errors (MAEs) for validation set, which is called CV score. Upper confidence bound (UCB) was used as the acquisition function. The suggestion of feasible hyperparameter was repeated until all the predefined trials were exhausted, resulting in the optimized hyperparameter set (See 2. Methods for the details). The CV scores of the four ML models were compared (Fig. 2b, Table S5). LASSO showed the worst accuracy with CV score of 0.45 (±0.03) eV. CV scores of RF and XGB were 0.25 (±0.02) eV and 0.19 (±0.03) eV, respectively. DNN model showed the best CV score of 0.18 (±0.02) eV. Thus, after hyperparameter tuning, the DNN model with the best validation MAE (MAEvalid) (6th fold) was chosen out of 10 folds for further analysis of prediction ability and the prediction of E segr (Fig. 2c, Tables S1, S6). Among 1366 data, 140 data were used as test data and the remaining 1226 data were used as training/validation data. As the 123 validation data were randomly chosen out of the 1226 data for each fold while the rest were used as training data, the MAEvalid is likely to only measure the interpolative prediction ability of the model. Thus, 140 data with (643) facet (h = 6, k = 4, l = 3), which were not present in the training/validation data, were chosen as test data to measure extrapolative prediction ability of the DNN model, especially for Miller indices (h, k, l) and ΔCN features (Fig. S2). The DNN model reproduced the E segr of training data well, showing good parity with training MAE (MAEtrain)=0.05 eV (Fig. 2d). The model also showed good parity for validation data with MAEvalid=0.13 eV, showing reasonable interpolative predicting accuracy (Table S7). Test MAE (MAEtest) for the (643) facet data was 0.13 eV, indicating reasonable extrapolative predicting accuracy for unseen Miller index features. Considering that the test data includes the data with CN=11 (ΔCN=12–11=1), which was not included in the training/validation data, the MAE of 0.08 eV for these data indicates the extrapolative predicting accuracy for ΔCN feature. As the data set includes a broad range of 552 (=24 × 24 – 24) elemental combinations of 3d, 4d, and 5d group transition metals, the trained model is likely to accurately predict the change of the E segr with respect to elemental combinations within the d group metals. The E segr of an impurity atom with atom number of Z + 1 within a host metal with atom number of Z can be experimentally obtained by photoemission spectroscopy of surface core-level shift (SCLS) within Z + 1 approximation [38]. Six experimental E segr data by SCLS (E segr,SCLS) were collected from literature (Table S8) [39]. The MAE for the six E segr,SCLS data (MAEexpt) was 0.10 eV, indicating that the DNN model well reproduces the experimental E segr values. To examine whether the MAEs for validation (MAEvalid) and test data (MAEtest) measure interpolative and extrapolative prediction abilities of the model, respectively, the distribution of the total 1366 data was visualized. Principal component analysis (PCA) is a useful tool to reduce the dimension of the data, enabling the visualization of high-dimensional data on two-dimensional plot. Thus, the 1366 data were projected onto the PC1-PC2 plane by maximizing the variance of the projected data; PC1: 1st principal component 1; PC2: 2nd principal component (See 2. Methods for the details) (Fig. 2e). During the projection, 55.68% of variation was preserved by choosing PC1 and PC2 (Fig. S3). The validation data were shown to be present inside the region of training data because they were randomly chosen within the 1226 data. Experimental SCLS data were also within the training data region. As expected, on the other hand, the test data turned out to be present outside of the training/validation data region. Therefore, the MAEvalid (MAEexpt) and MAEtest actually measure the interpolative and extrapolative prediction abilities of the trained DNN model, respectively. Finally, all the 1366 data were used to make the final DNN model to be used for the applications in the following sections. The MAEtrain, MAEvalid, and MAEexpt of the final DNN model were 0.05, 0.13, and 0.08 eV, respectively. 3.3 Feature importance analysis by explainable artificial intelligence approach Explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) concept is a useful approach to extract physical insights from ML model as it gives explanation for the predicted results. Classic Shapley value was first introduced in economics field to give a solution to the problem of fairly determining the contribution of each player participating in cooperative game [40]. SHAP value was later proposed to apply the concept of Shapley value to explanation of complex ML models trained on large data set [15]. The SHAP value can intuitively quantify directional impact of each feature on the model output (See 2. Methods for the details). SHAP values for the whole 1366 samples were calculated, providing directional feature importance to the corresponding E segr values (Figs. 3 a, S4). The ε im was found to be the most influential on the E segr. As the feature value of ε im decreases, the impact on the model output (SHAP value) becomes more negative, i.e., the lower the ε im value is, the more negative the E segr value is likely to be. Thermodynamically, a nanoparticle (NP) prefers to lower its total surface free energy, so larger exposure of metal components with low surface energy (or ε) on the surface would be favorable, reducing total surface free energy. Thus, it makes sense that a low-ε impurity element favors to be segregated to the host metal's surface. On the other hand, as the ε h decreases, the impact on the E segr becomes more positive. It can be understood that the decrease of ε h leads to the relative increase of ε im, so the impurity metal would less favor the surface position, resulting in the increase of E segr. The E segr decreases as the Δε decreases. According to the definition of Δε (= ε im - ε h), its decrease indicates the decrease of ε im and/or the increase of ε h. Thus, the decrease of E segr by the decrease of Δε is consistent with the tendencies of SHAP values of ε im and ε h. Therefore, selecting a metal element with lower surface energy, compared to host metal, as an impurity metal would be beneficial for thermodynamically favorable segregation of the impurity metal (decrease of E segr). This is also in agreement with the finding by Alden et al. that the difference of the surface energies of impurity and host metals are critical for the segregation of impurity metal, which was consistent with experimental SCLS of 4d and 5d transition metals [41]. Other than ε-related features, r was found to have the second largest impact on the E segr values. As the r im increased, the impact on the E segr became negative. Relatively larger size of impurity metal than that of host metal would cause stronger local strain around the impurity metal's position inside the host metal lattice, so the SHAP value tendency of r im also physically makes sense [30,31]. Similar to the case of the ε-related features, the tendency of r h is opposite to that of r im, and the E segr accordingly decreases with the increase of Δr. Thus, selecting the metal element with relatively larger size, compared to host metal, as an impurity metal will lead to the favorable surface segregation. The ΔCN feature was found to have the third largest impact on the E segr values. However, the ΔCN's SHAP values showed no clear directional tendency. Apparently, CN of the impurity metal's segregation site seems to have nonnegligible impact on the E segr, considering the large SHAP values. Thus, the directional tendency of ΔCN might depend on the choice of elemental combination, which was found to be more influential on the E segr than ΔCN in the analyses of ε- and r-related features’ SHAP values. According to previous works, the E segr’s dependency on the CN is actually different with respect to the elemental combinations of impurity and host metals [26,42]. Particularly, Han et al. calculated surface segregation energies for various impurity-host combinations and facets using DFT calculations, and the segregation energies were shown to have various relationships with the CN, e.g., posivite/negative linear, convex, and concave relationships [9]. Miller index k was found to have the fourth largest impact on the E segr. The k’s SHAP values also have no clear directional tendency on the E segr. Similarly, the other Miller indices l and h also showed no directional tendency. This may be related with the absence of directionality in ΔCN feature's SHAP values because the Miller indices determine the exposed facets of NPs, which obviously lead to the change of the exposed metal site's CN. The absence of directional tendency for these structural features makes simple tendency-based prediction of E segr difficult, implying the necessity of fast screening of feature combinations by ML model to tailor E segr value. The remaining features are all elemental features, reflecting charge transfer effect between the impurity and host metals [26]. These features related with electronic effects were shown to have smaller effects on the E segr than thermodynamic (ε im, ε h, and Δε), and structural features (r im, ΔCN, and k) (Fig. 3a, b). Particularly, PEN-related features (PENim, PENh, and ΔPEN) showed no directional tendency, and EA- and IE-related features (EAim, EAh, ΔEA, IEim, IEh, and ΔIE) showed tendency similar to ε- and r-related features. However, these features related with electronic effects are not independently controllable and determined by the choice of elemental combination of impurity and host metals. Placing specific element at the outer shell of alloy NPs is critical to design highly reactive and costly effective alloy metal catalysts such as core-shell NPs and single atom alloy (SAA) because the change of surface composition by the surface segregation would lead to the change of surface-reactant interactions, leading to change of catalytic reactivity [5,43,44]. Therefore, enhanced alloy catalysts can be designed by controlling the E segr, which can be tuned by proper choice of elemental combination (surface energy and radius) and surface structures (CN and facet). 3.4 Example: Finding feasible metal combinations to design nanosegregated alloy catalysts Surface segregation can be used to design highly active catalysts. For example, core-shell alloy catalyst has been reported to efficiently promote many essential reactions [45,46]. The core-shell catalyst benefits from the dominant surface fraction of active metal in the shell with host metal in the core; the surface segregation can lead to the specific atomic arrangement. Thus, the amount of active metal can be reduced while still benefitting from metal mixing effects, represented as strain and ligand effect [47]. For instance, extremely low abundance and high price of highly ORR-active Pt electrode catalyst has been one of major barriers to the commercialization of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) [48]. Thus, making cost-effective Pt-based core-shell catalysts can be critical to lowering the barrier. The activity of the core-shell catalyst can be tuned by shape control into a variety of morphologies, such cubes, octahedral, and icosahedra, because highly active high-index facets can be mainly exposed on the surface depending on the morphology [48,49]. Another notable advantage of the shaped core-shell compared with the ordinary one is that surface atoms have various CNs, e.g., low-CN sites at edge and vertex, and high-CN sites at flat {111}-like facets. This indicates that, using proper impurity-host combination, the surface segregation can preferably occur at highly-active low-CN site, leading to site-selective nanosegregated alloy catalyst. Therefore, if the active impurity metal is selectively placed at the low-CN sites of host metal, such as edge and vertex, by the site-selective segregation, most of active metals are likely to show high intrinsic activity due to their low CN. Simultaneously, the used amount of active metals can be saved as is in ordinary core-shell catalysts, so improved activity per used amount of the active metal can be achieved. Thus, examination of CN-dependency of E segr can be helpful to find proper elemental combination that can lead to the low CN-selective surface segregation. As an example, the DNN-predicted E segr was used to explain the formation of site-selective nanosegregated Pt-Ni octahedron alloy catalysts from a thermodynamic perspective (Fig. 4 a). Changing the CN from 12 (bulk or subsurface) to 4, the corresponding E segr were predicted by the DNN model. When Pt and Ni were set as impurity and host metals, respectively, all the predicted E segr values were negative, indicating that the segregation of Pt towards the Ni NP's surface is thermodynamically favored. On top of that, the E segr values decreased as the CN decreased, meaning that the surface segregation of Pt towards low-CN site is preferred to high-CN site; red E segr values mapped onto vertex and edges sites of the octahedron NP structure demonstrates this tendency (Figs. 4a, S1). Thus, the site-selective Pt nanosegregation at vertex and edge sites can be explained by the E segr’s dependency on CN. Oh et al. actually reported the synthesis of phase-segregated octahedral Pt-Ni nanoparticle where Pt impurity metals are mainly present at edges and vertices [50]. Conversely, when Pt and Ni were set as host and impurity metals, respectively, the E segr values were all positive regardless of CN, showing why the Ni should be used as a host metal to make the nanosegregated Pt alloy catalyst; blue E segr values on the NP structure show that the segregation is not favorable. Although there may be other factors affecting the surface segregation, such as surface stabilization agents or diffusion path [50], E segr suggests us a key criteria of thermodynamic preference for the formation of the nanosegregated catalyst. For many catalytic applications, active metals other than Pt may be necessary, and use of economically more efficient host metal is important for the industrial synthesis of the nanosegregated alloy catalysts. Besides, choosing a proper elemental impurity-host combination was found to be the most impactful factor on the E segr in the previous section. Thus, the prediction of thermodynamically feasible elemental combinations would be highly beneficial to choosing proper metals for specific applications. Therefore, 552 (=24 × 24–24) combinations of 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metals were screened by the DNN model using the following screening criteria (Fig. 4b): (1) E segr CN = 12 < 0.13 eV, (2) E segr at lower CN sites should be lower than at higher CN sites. First criterion indicates the physical validity that bulk-to-bulk or bulk-to-subsurface segregation should be thermodynamically neutral or favorable, respectively, within the error range of the DNN model. Second criterion indicates the favorability of segregation towards the low-CN sites, which would be beneficial for site-selective surface segregation of impurity metal. After the screening process, 44 elemental combinations passed the criteria (Fig. S5); the difference of E segr ( Δ E segr = E segr CN = 4 − E segr CN = 12 ) measures how much the segregation to low-CN site is favorable. Among them, six metals were found to be feasible candidates as host metals to make the nanosegregated Pt catalyst, which might be active for ORR: Co, Ni, Mo, Rh, W, and Os (Figs. 4b, c, Table S9). All the six host metals showed monotonically decreasing E segr tendency (favorability of surface segregation at low-CN sites). Out of six candidates, Rh showed poorer site-selectivity of the segregation than the already-reported Ni host. Co showed similar site-selectivity to Ni while Mo, W, and Os showed better selectivity than Ni; the E segr values mapped on the each host metal's Wulff structure demonstrate the poorest site-selectivity of Rh and the best site-selectivity of W. Particularly, among the six candidate host metals, Ni and Co have been reported to be able to show anisotropic phase segregation of Pt impurity; this shows the validity of DNN-based host metal screening process [6,50–53]. Meanwhile, 12 metals were found to be feasible as host metals for nanosegregated Cu catalyst, which have potential to be active for CO2RR: Ir, OS, Re, W, Ta, Ru, Tc, Mo, Ni, Co, Fe, and Cr (Fig. S5a). Among them, choosing a metal, which is cheaper than Cu active to the CO2RR, as the host metal would lead to the efficient Cu alloy catalyst for CO2RR. Site-selective nanosegregated alloy catalysts as described above can also be used as base materials to make nanoframe catalysts. Nanoframe catalyst can be obtained by etching with a proper acid agent to selectively remove host metal in the nanosegregated alloy, leaving skeletal framed structure mainly composed of impurity metal [6]. Nanoframe catalyst has been considered as a promising catalyst that can significantly enhance the efficiency of electrocatalytic reactions because it shows highly large surface area, high intrinsic activity, and/or stability. Pt-Ni alloy, one of combinations found by our screening, has been used as the base material for Pt nanoframe catalysts. Chen et al. made open-framework structure of Pt based on nanosegregated Pt-Ni alloy NP, demonstrating the superior ORR activity to that of conventional Pt/C catalyst [51]. Oh et al. also synthesized similar Pt-rich skeletal alloy catalyst using anisotropic nanoscale phase segregation and host metal-selective etching afterwards, showing greatly improved ORR activity [50]. As another example, since Au catalyst has been reported to be active to electrocatalytic reactions such as CO2RR and methanol oxidation [54,55], several previous works have made Au nanoframe catalysts [55–58]. However, their syntheses were not segregation-based, but based on Ag template-directed galvanic replacement; this may be because the site-selective surface segregation of Au in Ag host is not thermodynamically favorable as was shown by our screening result (Fig. 4b). 3.5 Guidance for further data collection to develop more accurate segregation energy model Information on the data distribution can allow us to qualitatively estimate the prediction ability of a model that was trained on the data, e.g., a data distribution localized at a particular region in feature space would give poor generality of prediction. Thus, the information can also give insights on how to add more data to improve the accuracy of the model [18]. As introduced in the previous section, PCA is a useful data-science technique to visualize the distribution of high-dimensional data in low-dimensional space. Thus, the 1366 E segr data were further analyzed by PCA to extract insights on the data distribution. Each principal component (PC) can be represented as a linear combination of original feature variables. Thus, the weight of each feature for a PC indicates how much the feature changes with following the PC. Weights of features for PC1 and PC2 were calculated and they were roughly categorized into the two groups: structural features (h, k, l, and ΔCN) and elemental features (ε im, ε h, Δε, r im, r h, Δr, PENim, PENh, ΔPEN, IEim, IEh, ΔIE, EAim, EAh, and ΔEA) (Fig. S6a, Table S10). Structural features were shown to have larger weights on PC1 axis, and elemental features larger weights on PC2 axis, indicating that the PC1 is likely to have information on the distribution of structural features, and the PC2 the distribution of elemental features. Regular PCA usually has disadvantage that it has non-zero weights for all the variables (features), making it difficult to interpret the PCA result. Sparse PCA can alleviate this disadvantage of the regular PCA by applying L1 penalty on the weight values, limiting the number of feature with non-zero weight [19]. Therefore, sparse PCA was used to differentiate the two feature groups clearer (Fig. S6b, Table S10). After the sparse PCA, the structural features were found to have non-zero weights only for the PC1. Only eight elemental features survived the sparse PCA, and the remaining features of impurity metal (r im, PENim, IEim, and EAim) were found to have larger weights than the features of host and their differences in the same category (F h and ΔF). Thus, the whole data in the PC space were plotted with respect to structural features and the chosen four elemental features (r im, PENim, IEim, and EAim) (Figs. 5 a–h). The four structural features were found to actually change along the PC1 axis (Figs. 5a–d). For instance, the data for various facets, such as (100), (001), (111), (322), (643), and (531), were distributed in a grouped manner, with the change of PC1 values (Fig. 5a). The ΔCN was also found to change along the PC1, but less drastically than Miller indices particularly at high PC1 region (Fig. 5d). On the other hand, the four elemental features were found to change mainly along the PC2 axis (Figs. 5e–h). Thus, the distribution of the structural and elemental features can be analyzed by investigating the data distribution along the PC1 and PC2, respectively. Kernel density estimate (KDE) plot showed that the data distribution along the structural axis (PC1) has some valleys in the middle of the distribution (Fig. 5i), and most of the data are concentrated at low-index facet region ((100), (001), and (111)) while small number of data are placed at high-index facet region (Fig. 5a). It indicates that the accuracy of the DNN model that was trained on these data might be poor for unseen high-index facets (Miller indices features) or unseen CNs although our DNN model showed pretty good accuracy for unseen facet and CN, e.g., (643) facet and CN=11. Therefore, the model's predicting accuracy for structural features can be further improved by collecting more data with unseen facets and CNs, filling the valleys of the data distribution along structural axis. The KDE plot along the elemental axis (PC2) showed nearly normal distribution without any valley. Thus, the predicting accuracy for elemental choice would be stably good within the elemental combinations of (24 × 24) 3d, 4d, and 5d group transition metals. However, since the PC1 data distribution at high-index region (high PC2 region) are still sparse, data with various elemental combinations should be collected more for unseen structures (facet and CN), especially for the high-index region, to further improve the accuracy of the model. 4 Conclusion DFT-calculated E segr collected from the previous papers were featurized by inexpensive 19-dimensional numerical fingerprint, and were used to train several ML models. The ML models were rigorously trained by hyperparameter tuning based on Bayesian optimization scheme, and were compared using 10-fold CV, showing DNN as the best model. The interpolative and extrapolative predicting abilities of the DNN model were analyzed to be fairly good by data splitting and PCA. The DNN model was also used to extract directional influence of each feature on the E segr value using XAI approach. Surface energy and radius of metal elements were found to be the most impactful on the E segr, indicating that the proper choice of elemental combination would be critical to tune the E segr of alloy metal. Therefore, by screening 552 elemental combinations of transition metals, 44 combinations were found to be feasible to form the site-selective nanosegregated alloy catalysts, which can potentially be used as base materials for the synthesis of nanoframe catalysts. Moreover, six candidate host metals were also found to be feasible to show site-selective surface segregation of Pt. Two of them turned out to be already synthesized, validating the screening result. We also suggested data collection strategies based on PCA and sparse PCA to further improve the accuracy of the DNN model, which will show better interpolative and extrapolative prediction abilities. Furthermore, we expect that addition of the other factors affecting the surface segregation, such as the impurity/host ratio, adsorbate molecule on the surface, and directional dependency of impurity migration, would lead to more accurate E segr model in the future. The featurization of E segr by inexpensive numerical fingerprint that we presented here is useful because each feature can be easily obtained from literature or set by the user. Thus, massive prediction of E segr for a vast range of elemental combinations and surface structures is allowed, thanks to the rapid prediction of E segr by DNN. We thus believe our ML framework to predict E segr can be used to various applications that require the surface composition change of alloy catalysts and the design of segregation-based alloy catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Metal alloy catalysts have been known to enhance many essential reactions. Surface-adsorbate interaction of an alloy catalyst depends on the composition and nanostructure of the surface, which can be changed by a phenomenon called surface segregation. Thus, thermodynamic information on the surface segregation is critical to tune the surface-adsorbate interaction, and thus the reactivity of alloy catalysts. Collected 1,366 density functional theory-calculated segregation energies (E segr) from literature were featurized by 19-dimensional inexpensive numerical fingerprint, which represents facet-, site-, and elemental-dependencies. Deep neural network (DNN) model was constructed based on the data. Reasonable interpolative and extrapolative prediction by the DNN was clearly demonstrated using principal component (PC) analysis. On top of that, impact of each feature on the E segr was analyzed by an explainable artificial intelligence approach, giving useful insights for alloy catalyst design based on surface segregation. As an example of the applications, the DNN model was used to explain the formation thermodynamics of site-selective nanosegregated Pt alloy catalyst, and was also used to perform elemental screening to find impurity-host metal combinations feasible to form the nanosegregated alloy catalyst. In addition, the guidance for data collection to improve the DNN model was given by analyzing PC space and performing the weight analysis of PCs.
coredata.dc:title: Surface segregation machine-learned with inexpensive numerical fingerprint for the design of alloy catalysts
